titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Unity Club records ARC.102
titlestmt.author: Nicholas Pavlik
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-08-21 11:21:39 +0000.

did.abstract: This collection consists of a bound volume containing a register of the Unity Club's members for the period 1914 to 1944. The register contains each member's name, home and business address, and occupation, as well as the names of the members who proposed and seconded his membership nomination. Also included is a program from the Unity Club's 70th anniversary dinner, and a framed painting commemorating the Club's 50th anniversary in 1946, picturing the three clubhouses occupied by the Club since its founding.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Source and date of acquisition unknown.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Minimally processed to the collection level.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Unity Club records, ARC.102, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Founded in 1896, the Unity Club was a Brooklyn Jewish men's organization advocating social, philanthropic, and communal activities. Originally located at Franklin Avenue and Hancock Street, the Club relocated to a clubhouse at Dean Street and Bedford Avenue in 1914, and again to a clubhouse at 101 Eighth Avenue in 1944.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of a bound volume containing a register of the Unity Club's members for the period 1914 to 1944. The register contains each member's name, home and business address, and occupation, as well as the names of the members who proposed and seconded his membership nomination. Also included is a program from the Unity Club's 70th anniversary dinner, and a framed painting commemorating the Club's 50th anniversary in 1946, picturing the three clubhouses occupied by the Club since its founding.
